source.df7b5d81:
#Brazilian Senate approves new legal framework for basic sanitation in Brazil

by Eliane Oliveira and Manoel Ventura,24/06/2020. 

The measure, approved by the Chamber at the end of last year , may open up more space for private agents and attract investments in the sector. 

The project must change a dramatic picture: more than half of the Brazilian population has `no treated sewage` and about 35 million Brazilians do `not have access to drinking water.`

The estimate by the government and private sector experts is that around R $ 700 billion will be needed for this situation to be corrected by 2033, reducing infrastructure deficiencies that leave 104 million Brazilians `without sewage services`.

The new sanitation regulatory framework in the country is also seen as important for attracting investments in the post-pandemic. Basic sanitation is the last infrastructure sector that has not been liberalized, unlike segments such as telephony and energy.  

The text provides for bids for the contracting of water and sewage companies, which opens the way for the entry of private initiative in the sector, which will now compete on equal terms with state-owned companies.

Both public and private companies will have to meet universalization goals, to be achieved by the end of 2033. Until then, 99 per cent coverage is expected for water supply and 90 per cent for sewage collection and treatment.

https://translate.google.com.br/translate?hl=en&sl=pt&u=https://oglobo.globo.com/economia/senado-aprova-novo-marco-legal-para-saneamento-basico-no-brasil-24496471&prev=search&pto=aue
source.316521f2:
georank.org -Proof that COVID-19 Data Accuracy depends on countries' development levels

If COVID-19 data accuracy did not depend on countries' levels of development, then there would be no correlation between the number of countries' confirmed coronavirus cases per 100,000 people and GDP per capita, the Human Freedom Index, or the Corruption Perceptions Index.

A correlation coefficient values range from -1 to 1 and indicate relationships between two variables, where -1 is the absolute negative correlation, 0 is the absence of correlation, and 1 is the absolute correlation.

There is a strong statistically significant correlation between countries' confirmed COVID-19 cases and GDP per capita. The correlation coefficient is 0.8 (95 per cent CI: 0.74 - 0.85), which wouldn't have existed if the data accuracy was the same in every country.

The chart includes only countries with a population of more than 300,000 people. Otherwise small countries like the Vatican would distort the values of confirmed cases per 100,000 people.

But even for the sample of all 197 countries, the correlation coefficient is 0.49 (95 per cent CI: 0.38 - 0.59) that is still a strong statistically significant correlation.

Confirmed COVID-19 cases per 100,000 people also correlate with the Human Freedom Index (by Cato Institute) and the Corruption Perceptions Index (by Transparency International).
source.2d3d33de:
#Population with basic handwashing facilities at home (Per cent)

The JMP assembles, reviews and assesses national data collected by statistics offices and other relevant institutions including sectoral authorities. Linear regression is used to provide estimates of the population with handwashing facilities at home, as well as the proportion with handwashing facilities where soap and water were observed.

Separate estimates are made for urban and rural areas, and national estimates are generated as weighted averages of the two, using population data from the most recent report of the United Nations Population Division. The most recent household survey or census available for most countries was typically conducted two to six years ago. 

The JMP (Joint Monitoring Programme) extrapolates regressions for two years beyond the last available data point. Beyond this point the estimates remain unchanged for up to four years unless coverage is below 0.5 per cent or above 99.5 per cent, in which case the line is extended indefinitely. For more information see https://washdata.org/monitoring/methods/estimation-methods Predominant type of statistics: adjusted and predicted. 

https://www.who.int/data/gho/indicator-metadata-registry/imr-details/4822
source.b9475dee:
![](https://erj.ersjournals.com/content/erj/32/5/1415/F1.medium.gif)

Relationship between per capita gross domestic product (GDP; Wold Bank data, 2005) and incidence of tuberculosis per 100,000 population. For graphical presentation, the third root of the population (millions) divided by 10 was used to determine the size of the symbols. This arbitrary choice provides a visual appreciation that large sized populations do not bear an excessive weight at the extremes of the axes, but are rather distributed across the entire scale. Both abscissa and ordinate were drawn logarithmically. 1; India; 2: China; 3: UK.https://erj.ersjournals.com/content/32/5/1415
source.76763455:
The correlation between GDP and TB for India, China and the UK. The regression analysis suggests that each doubling of GDP was associated with a 38.5 percent decrease in the incidence of TB. For instance, the ratio of per capita GDP between India and China is ∼2.3 and the incidence of TB is 40 per cent lower in China than in India.

The take-home message is clear and emphasises a major thrust of the World Health Organization’s strategy: to stop tuberculosis, we must fight poverty. https://erj.ersjournals.com/content/32/5/1415
source.3d16cb75:
#GEORANK.ORG Oddsome (best) graphs I ever seen about the Pandemic. Georanks' Charts rule!  

#What does they all mean?

It proves that the number of confirmed coronavirus cases in each country is literally what the country has managed to detect.

But little it says about the actual numbers, especially in developing countries, as testing policies and capabilities vary greatly. In my country, I don't know anyone that has made the test. 

Therefore: It would make little sense to blame countries solely for being at the top of the infected list, as it's like blaming for being transparent and capable. TRANSPARENCY with the Data!

While comparing ACCURACY of the data depends on the level of a country's development.https://georank.org/articles/gdppc-covid-correlation
source.81e6b656:
#Progress on drinking water, sanitation and hygiene

Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) 2017 update and SDG baselines

The JMP 2017 update report presents indicators and baseline estimates for the drinking water, sanitation and hygiene targets within the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). The report introduces the indicators of safely managed drinking water and sanitation services, which go beyond use of improved facilities, to include consideration of the quality of services provided. For the first time, hygiene estimates are reported for 70 countries. https://www.who.int/water_sanitation_health/publications/jmp-2017/en
source.fb727c80:
#An ecological analysis of incidence of tuberculosis and per capita gross domestic product

By J-P. Janssens, H. L. Rieder-European Respiratory Journal 2008 32: 1415-1416; DOI: 10.1183/09031936.00078708 

In 2006, an estimated 9 million new cases of tuberculosis (TB) emerged worldwide 1. Of these, only 1% occurred in the European Union and North America combined, while Africa and South-East Asia contributed >65 per cent. Among the 22 high-burden countries, 17 were in Africa, 16 of which were in the lowest quartile in terms of per capita gross domestic product (GDP). Since 2001, the fight against poverty has been a major theme in the World Health Organization’s (WHO) “Stop TB” strategy. Indeed, poverty “fuels” TB by facilitating transmission through crowded working and living conditions, it may increase the risk of progression to disease through malnutrition, and imposes barriers to accessing health services.

The World Bank publishes yearly estimates of per capita GDP per country. Similarly, the WHO provides annual estimates for TB incidence for each country by WHO region. Of the 211 WHO member states and 177 countries with reports by the World Bank, there were 171 pairs with information on both GDP and TB. For uniformity of the denominator, United Nations population estimates for 2004 were used to obtain per capita figures for GDP and TB, respectively.

The choice of the same denominator permitted a direct regression on the numerators (rather than on rates), using population size as a weight. Linear regression on the logarithm of both TB (2004) and GDP (2005) was chosen as the intuitively simplest model. Both unweighted (not shown) and weighted regression gave similar results.
https://erj.ersjournals.com/content/32/5/1415
